channel.title: About the Parsing category
channel.description:
One of the most popular and developed dialects in Rebol is the PARSE dialect.
* [Original Introduction in Rebol2 Documentation](http://rebol.com/docs/core23/rebolcore-15.html)
* [Red's writeup when adding the feature](https://www.red-lang.org/2013/11/041-introducing-parse.html)
* [Old PARSE Tutorial from what was `codeconscious.com`](https://forum.rebol.info/t/old-parse-tutorial/1771)
Some evolutions of the PARSE dialect were introduced by [a spin-off called "Topaz"](https://github.com/giesse/red-topaz-parse), which added the idea of parse expressions synthesizing a value--in addition to advancing the input. These values could then be captured by SET-WORD! (instead of capturing the parse position in the set word variable, as the original PARSE did).
Ren-C more aggressively evolved the dialect to be based on functions that could be written in userspace--a parallel to "parser combinators". This implementation is called UPARSE:
https://forum.rebol.info/t/introducing-the-hackable-usermode-parse-uparse/1529

These values could then be captured by SET-WORD! (instead of capturing the parse position in the set word variable, as the original PARSE did).

Ren-C more aggressively evolved the dialect to be based on functions that could be written in userspace--a parallel to "parser combinators". This implementation is called UPARSE:

Introducing The Hackable Usermode PARSE ("UPARSE") Parsing
!!! BIG NEWS !!! I've griped about historical PARSE's weaknesses for some time. To name a few: Users can't add new keywords, or tweak existing ones. It's a monolithic chunk of C code that you have to recompile to get any changes to. And since Rebol2's heyday, there have arisen a competitive landscape of "parser combinators" which allow users to build new parse "keywords" and compose parsers out of each other.
